Ayssi comensan las paraulas de Albucasim .	Thus begin the words of Albucasis. (I'm assuming "Albucasim" is an alternative spelling for Abu al-Qasim, a famous Andalusian physician who wrote medical texts in Arabic.)
O, filhs, pus yeu he a vos complit aquest libre, le qual es le derier de la sciencia de medicina, per le compliment de lu so consequit la fi en lu, e per las exposicios de lu, e per las declaracios de lu, es a mi vist que yeu complesca aquel a vos am aquest tractat, le qual es partida de la operacio am ma, so es cyrurgia.	Oh, son, as I have completed this book for you, which is the culmination of the medical science, and in fulfilling it, I have decided to present to you this treatise, which is a part of the practice with my hands, that is, surgery.
Quar la operacio am ma es prostrada en nostre regio e en nostre temps de tot privada, entro que fort leu peric la sciencia de lu, e le vistigi de lu es ostat; e no romasero de lu sino alcunas petitas descripcios en les libres dels Antics, les quals mudero las mas e endevenc ad aquels error e heyssitacio entro que son clausas las entencios de lu e es elonguada la forsa de lu e l’art.	For the practice with our hands is prohibited in our region and time, so that the science of it quickly perishes and its traces are lost; and there will remain from it only a few small descriptions in the books of the Ancients, which I have altered and rendered obscure with errors and confusion, so that the meanings of it are closed off and the power and art of it are weakened.
E es vist a mi que yeu vivifique aquela am ordenacio de aquest tractat en aquela segon la via de exposicio e de declaracio e de abreviacio; e per que vengua am las formas dels ferramentz de cautheri e dels autres instrumentz de la obra cum sia per addicio de la declaracio, e per preparacio de lu, la qual causa es necessaria.	And it seems to me that I should revive that practice with this treatise in a second way through explanation, clarification, and abbreviation; and may it come with the forms of the cautery tools and other instruments of the work as an addition to the explanation and preparation, which is necessary.
Mays la causa per la qual no es atrobat bo artifex am la sieua ma en aquest nostre temps, es quar la art de medicina es longua, e que cove le sieu actor denant aquo esser excercitat en la sciencia de anotomia la qual recontec Gualia entro que sapia les juvament dels membres e las formas de aquels, e la conjunctio e la separacio de lor; e haia la conoyssensa dels osses, dels nervis e dels lacertz, e·l nombre de aquels, e la egrecio de lor; e de las venas pulsatils e de las quietas, e dels locs del eyssiment de lor.	But the reason why a skilled craftsman with his hand is not found in our time is because the art of medicine is vast, and it requires that its practitioner be well-versed in anatomy, as Galen said, which means knowing the functions of members and their forms, as well as their junctions and separations; and having knowledge of bones, nerves, and tendons, as well as their number and function; and of the veins, both those that pulse and those that do not, as well as the places where they emerge.
E per aquo ditz Ypocras que am u nom es mot, mays en l’obra petit, e majorment en la art de la ma.	And for this reason Hippocrates said that a name is one thing, but the work is another, and even more so in the art of hand-work (i.e., surgery).
Mays nos ja avem dit de aquel en l’introit de aquest libre; quar qui no es scient aquo que li avem dit de anotomia, no es evacuat que no caia en error per la qual siran mortz les homes, ayssi cum yeu he vist trops de aquels, quar alscus son formatz en esta sciencia e gettan se de aquela ses sciencia e ses experiment.	But we have already said this at the beginning of this book; for whoever does not know what we have said about anatomy is not able to avoid falling into error, which can result in death, as I have seen too often. For some are educated in this science but then abandon it and its knowledge and experience.
Quar yeu vi un metge folh e enperit aver incidit un apostema escrophilos en le colh de una femna, e incidic alcunas arterias del colh per que fluic gran sanc entro que la femna cazec morta entre las mas de lu.	For I saw a foolish doctor who attempted to incise an abscess in a woman's neck and cut some of the arteries in the neck, causing a great deal of blood to flow out so that the woman died in his arms.
E vi un autre metge que pres que el traguera una peyra d’un home le qual avia procesit en sa etat, e la peyra era gran, e venguet a lu e trayssec aquela peyra am un tros de la vesiqua, per que aquel home al tertz dia es mort.	And I saw another doctor who attempted to extract a stone from a man's bladder, which was large, and it came out along with a piece of the bladder, causing the man to die three days later.
E yeu ja apelat fuy a estrayre aquela, e vi que per la grandesa de la peyra e per la disposicio del malaute conogui subre lu que morira.	And I, too, have seen similar cases where I advised against operating and recognized from the size of the stone and the patient's condition that they would die.
E vi un autre metge le qual prenia stipendic de un duc de nostra terra per cyrurgia, e endeven a un crastrat negre le qual era deves lu fractura en la coyssa de lu; e perparec le metge am la sua ignorancia, estrayssec la fractura, sobre la plagua, am pulvinas e astelas am forta strectura, e no layssec a la plagua espiracio.	And I saw another doctor who was paid by a duke in our land to perform surgery, and he treated a black castrate who had a fracture in his thigh; and through his ignorance, the doctor bandaged the fracture with tight padding and splints over the wound, without allowing it to breathe. [Quar per estraysser aquela fractura sobre la carn e no laysser espiracio, yeu vi que en quinze dies es mort lo crastrat; e si lu avia estraysset sots le pell de aquel loc, e non sobre la carn, e layssant espiracio, vivriya longa temps.
E aprop le desliet segons los sieus desiriers, e aprop le relieg, e aprop le leyssec per alcus jorns e comandec que nos deslies le liament; e estec ayssi entro que la coyssa e·l pe foro apostematz, e pervenguet a perdicio.	And he treated him according to his own desires, binding and unbinding the wound at times, commanding that they rebind it as he saw fit; and this went on for some days until both the thigh and leg became abscessed and progressed to perdition.
E yeu fuy apelat a lu, e aparelhegui a desliar le liament, e conseguida es tranquilitat e enayssi amermet de sas dolors.	And I was called to him and prepared to unbind the bandages, and after doing so, he became calm and relieved of his pain.
Mays empero ja corrupcio era confermada en le membre, per que no pogui refrenar aquela, e no cessec perambular la corrupcio en le membre entro que·l malaute peric.	But the corruption had already become established in the limb, and I was unable to contain it; the corruption continued to spread through the limb until the patient's life was in danger. [E aprop lo metge e comansset fayre cauterizacions per le joventz del malaute, e non por aquel remedio que no morisca.
E vi un autre metge le qual perforec un apostema cancros, e fo ulcerat aprop alscus dias, entro que foc magnificada la malicia de lu am lo senhor de lu.	And I saw another doctor who lanced a cancerous abscess, and it became ulcerated after several days, causing the illness to become more severe in its master (i.e., the patient).
La qual causa es quar le cranc caut es pur de humor melencolic, lahoras no cove que pervengua a lu am ferr de tot, sino que sia an membre le qual suffertes que de tot fos hostat.	The reason for this is that the cancerous growth is full of black bile; therefore, it should not be treated with cauterization in all cases, but rather on a member that can tolerate it being host to the growth.
E per aquo, filhs, necessari es a vos que la operacio am ma sia devisada en dos devesios: so es en operacio a lu qual es associada salut, e en obra am la qual es perilh en las majors disposicios.	And so, son, it is necessary for you to divide the practice with your hands into two categories: one that is associated with health and the other that involves risk in the most serious conditions.
E yeu ja he exsitat aquo en tot loc de aquest libre en le qual venc opperacio en la qual es error e temor; per que necessari es a vos que guardetz aquo e layssetz aquel, per que les folhs no atrobo via a parlar e a vos desonestar.	And I have already explained this in all parts of this book, where I discuss the operation that involves error and fear; it is necessary for you to be careful and avoid it, so that the pages do not provide an opportunity for you to speak falsely and dishonor yourself.
E donc prenetz las vostras armas am sollicitut e am proteccio de Dieu , e les vostres malautes am falicitat e am fermetat.	And so, take up your arms with eagerness and protection from God, and treat your patients with skillfulness and confidence.
E usatz de la milhor via per la gracia de Dieu perdusent a salut e a lausabla successio, e laysatz las malautias terriblas de difficil sanacio, e ostatz las vostras armas de aquo que vos fa temer, per so que ysitatio en vostra fe e en le vostre nom no vos evasisca: quar mays es remanent a la vostra gloria, e pus aut en le mon e en derier a las vostras sanctitatz.	And use the best method through the grace of God to achieve success and praise; leave behind you terrible illnesses that are difficult to cure, and keep your weapons from those things that cause fear in you, so that your faith and reputation do not fail you: for it is more fitting for your glory, and for a lasting testament to your sanctity.
Gualia ja diyssec en alcunas sieuas monicios:	Galen also said in some of his monitions:
“No mediquetz malautia mala, per so que mals metges no siatz nompnatz”.	"Do not treat a bad illness badly, lest you be known as a bad doctor."
E yeu ja he devesit aquest libre segontz tres capitols.	I have divided this book into three chapters.
Comensa la divisio del libre, e primier de la primieyra partida.	Here begins the division of the book, and first of the first section.
Le primier capitol ordenat del cap entro·s pes, en las formas dels instrumentz e en les ferrementz dels cauteris, e de aquo que necessari es en la opperacio.	The first chapter deals with the head to the feet, including the forms of instruments and the irons of cauteries, as well as what is necessary for the operation.
La divisio de la segonda partida.	The division of the second section. [Quar entro le primiera e la secunda partida es les diversos locs del corp que son necesariamet opperatz per lo malautia, e en aquesta secunda partida es las armas de cauterizacions quals estan ordonadas per los sieus fers.
Le segon capitol, de siccio e perforacio, e de ventosas, e de plaguas, e de extractio de sagetas e de semblantz ad aquelas, tot capitolat e ordenat de las formas dels instrumentz.	The second chapter deals with dryness and punctures, cupping glasses, abscesses, and the extraction of arrows and similar things, all categorized and arranged by the forms of instruments.
Divisio de la tersa partida.	The division of the third section. (Note: This translation was provided by the original asker.)[Le tersa partida tracta de las maneiras diverses de sanar les ulceracions, e de las plaguas, entro que es una via per aquelas quals son amissibles a cauterizacion, e altre per aquelas quals no son amissibles a cauterizacio.
Le tertz capitol, de restauracio e de dislocacio, e de curacio de torcio e de semblantz ad aquels; capitol ordenat del cap entro·s pes, e de las formas dels instrumentz.	The third chapter deals with restoration and dislocation, as well as the treatment of twisting and similar things, arranged from head to foot and by the forms of instruments.
De cauteri am foc e am medicina aguda e rememoracio de la opperacio.	On cauterization with fire, sharp medicine, and a reminder of the operation. (Note: This translation was provided by the original asker.)[Quar en aquest ters capitol es tractat del cauteri am foc; e yeu ja he devisat que aquel sia de dos maneiras. Una so es le cauteri per forsa, laqual esset util en les plaguas quals son apres le ossa, entro que la carn es grosa. La otra maneyra del cauteri es am medicina aguda e remedio calent, la qual sia util entro los membrans quals son sens le ossa, per que no sien destruitz, e per aquo sia necessariamet preparat lo cauteri ab medicina aguda.
Am aquel comensa le tractat de tot le libre.	With this, the treatise of the entire book begins. (Note: This translation was provided by the original asker.)
Cove que yeu digua la qualitat dels juvamentz de aquel cauteri e dels noccumentz de lu, e en qual compleccio sia prohibit cauteri.	It is necessary for me to discuss the qualities of the benefits and harms of that cautery, as well as when it is prohibited to use cauterization. (Note: This translation was provided by the original asker.)
Donc dic que·l sermo de la qualitat del juvament de cauteri e del noccument de lu es sermo lonc e prolixs, e subtil per sciensa, e secret amaguat; e ja de lu a parlat gran multitut de savis, e de lu se son desacordatz, et a mi abasta un petit dels sermons de lor, temen perlonguacio.	Therefore I say that the discourse on the qualities of the benefits and harms of cautery is long and prolix, subtle in its science, and hidden in secrecy; many wise people have spoken about it already, and they disagree with one another, and I will touch upon only a small part of their words, for fear of being too lengthy. (Note: This translation was provided by the original asker.) [E dic que l’experientia me mostra que cauteri sia util en les plaguas e en las fissuras del corp, per aquo que·l calor de lu dissipa la melancolia de le sangre e·l humor de la plaga, e sana la fissura.
E donc dic que cauteri comfereys a tota compleccio universalment la qual es am materia o ses materia, exceptat dos compleccios, las quals son compleccios caudas ses materia .	And so I say that cautery cures all complexions universally, whether with or without material, except for two complexions, which are dry complexions without material.
En la compleccio cauda e secca am materia se desecordero; quar alcus dyssero que cauteri es juvatiu ad aquela, e les autres dyssero le contrari de aquel, que cauteri no es convenient en malautia la qual es per qualiditat e per siccitat, quar natura del foc es qualiditat e siccitat, e enconvenient es que malautia cauda e secca am aquo que es caut e sec sia sanada.	In the dry and hot complexion with material, (the use of) cautery is debated; for some say that cautery is beneficial to this complexion, while others say the opposite of this, that cautery is not appropriate in a disease that is caused by heat and dryness. This is because the nature of fire, which is used in cautery, is also hot and dry. It is not fitting to heal a disease that is dry and hot with something that is hot and dry.
E diysec aquel que ditz le contrari de aquel, que per cauteri es fayt juvament en tota malautia cauda e secca que ve en les cors dels homes, quar quan tu comparas le cors de home e las humiditatz de lu a la compleccio del foc, atrobas le cors de home freg.	And (I) disagree with the one who says the opposite, that cautery is beneficial in all cases of dry and hot diseases that appear in the bodies of men. This is because when you compare the bodies of humans and their humors to the nature of fire, you find that human bodies are cold.
E yeu dic per le sermo de aquel, que esperiment aquo ja a mi alscunas vetz a descubert.	And I say, based on what he has said, that I have experimented with this many times and discovered it to be true.
Mays empero no cove que vengua sobre aquo aquel que ja es exproat e excersitat en le capitol de cauteri per derier exercici, e a conogut la diversitat de la compleccio dels homes e la disposicio de las malautias en lor meteyssas, e las causas de aquelas, e·ls accidentz de lor, e l’espasi del temps de aquelas.	But it is not appropriate for someone who has not been proven and exercised in the chapter of cautery through previous experience to express an opinion on this matter. They have not come to know the diversity of human complexions and the various dispositions of diseases, as well as their causes and accidents, nor the space of time in which they occur.
Mays en las autras compleccios, no es sobre vos temor, e majorment en las malautias fregas e humidas, quar ja totz les metges se son acordatz sobre aquels, e no so desecordatz en le juvament am cauteri en aquelas.	But in other complexions, there is no reason to fear, especially in cold and wet diseases, for all doctors agree on this matter and are not divided on the use of cautery as a treatment for these types of illnesses.
E sapiatz, filhs, que del secret de curacio per cauteri am foc e de la bontat de lu, so sobre cauteri am medicina comburent, es quar le foc es simple, la accio del qual no perven sino al membre le qual es cauterizat e no notz al autre membre am lu ajustat sino am petit nocument.	And know, son, that the secret to healing through cautery with fire and its goodness lies in using a burning medicine as part of the cautery process, for fire is simple and its action only affects the specific area that is cauterized. It does not harm other parts of the body unless they are directly adjacent to the treated area.
Mays la accio de medicina comburent perven ad aquel en les membres le qual de lu alunhat, e fort leu fa venir en le membre malautia de dificil sanacio e fort leu ausit.	But the action of a burning medicine can also affect other parts of the body that are not directly treated with it, and it can quickly bring on difficult-to-heal disease and inflammation in those areas.
Mays le foc, per la sua sublimitat e de la sua substancia bontat, no fa aquo sino que superfluisca E ja es a nos conogut per experiment e per longitut de servitut de studi am l’art sobre le veritat de las causas; e per aquo yeu so excusat de la longitut del sermo E si no fos que no es legut al mieu libre en aquest pausero a vos secret amaguat am le foc, e la qualitat de la operacio de lu en les cors e de la sieua expulcio per la qual expellis las malautias, am sermo philosophic demostratiu, le qual siria acuit en las vostras pessas.	But fire, due to its sublime nature and inherent goodness, does not have this effect. This is known through experimentation and long study of the art and truth of causes. I will excuse myself from speaking at length on this matter. If it were not against the rules of this text, I would reveal to you the hidden secrets of fire and its operation in the body, as well as its expulsion, which removes illnesses. This could be demonstrated with philosophical language that would be useful for your studies.
E sapiatz, filhs, que els se desacordan del temps en le qual es convenient far cauteri e pausan le milhor temps de primaveyra.	And know, son, that they disagree on the timing of when it is appropriate to perform cautery and believe that the best time to do so is in the springtime.
E yeu dic que cauteri es convenient en tot temps, per so que le nocument per le temps accident es submergit en le juvament de aquo que am le cauteri es atirat, e majorment si le cauteri es per dolors o de dolors necessaries, fortz e fistinas, las quals no suffertan tarditat per so que es temut de aquelas que vengua malicia, que es major que petit nocument entrant per lo temps.	But I say that cautery is appropriate at any time, for the harm caused by accidental timing is outweighed by the benefits of using cautery as a treatment. This is especially true if cautery is necessary for severe and persistent pain that cannot be delayed, for the potential harm from waiting is greater than the small risk of harm from the timing of the procedure.
E aysso no catz en vostras pessas, o, filhs, aquo no estiman sino le poble vulguar e les fols metges, so es que ad aquela malautia que es sanada per cauteri no es redicio tot temps, e pausan aquel consequen.	And this is not the case in your studies, son, for only the ignorant masses and foolish doctors would think that a disease that can be cured with cautery should never be treated in such a way. They fail to consider the consequences of not using cautery when it is necessary.
E la causa no es ges ayssi quo els cuydan per aquo, quar cauteri no es sino en loc de medicina la qual altera la compleccio e esicca las humiditatz las quals son causa per que veno las dolors.	And the reason for this is not as they believe, for cautery is only used in place of a medicine that alters complexion and dries out the humors, which are the cause of pain.
Mays empero cauteri superflueys sobre la medicina per volicitat de la sua valitut e vertut de la sua operacio e grandesa del sieu senhor.	But nevertheless, cautery can be excessive in its use over medicine due to the strength and power of its operation and the greatness of its force.
E es possible que la sua malautia retorne en alcuna hora del temps, segon la compleccio del malaute e la locacio de la sua malautia, e la vertut de lu, e aquo que es preparat en le cors de lu de la agreguacio de las superfluitatz en lu, e aquo que es pervengut a lu en la sua acquisicio en viandas e semblantz de aquelas causas; sino que la malautia en la qual sia aministrat cauteri sia malautia subtil en membre de paucas superfluitatz e humiditatz, ayssi cum cauteri de dent per dolor e semblantz ad aquel, possible es que en lu no retorne aquela dolor, mays aquo se fa en petitz.	And it is possible that the patient's illness may return at some point in time, depending on their complexion and the location of the illness, as well as its strength, and any excesses present in their body from the accumulation of superfluous substances. This can occur due to the foods they consume and other causes. However, if cautery is administered for a subtle illness in an area with few superfluidities and humors, similar to a dental cauterization for pain, it is possible that the pain will not return, but this may only be temporary.
E mays sermo vulgar es que cauteri es le derier remezi de medicina, e es sermo dreyturier, no ad aquo que els entendo en lu, quar els crezo que no es curacio que aprofieyta am medicina ni am autra causa aprop cauteri.	And the common saying is that cautery is the last resort of medicine, and this is a true statement, although I do not interpret it in the same way as you do. I believe that there is no cure to be found through medicine or any other means except through the use of cautery.
E la causa es en contrari de aquo; e la entencio que cauteri es le derier remezi de medicina no es sino quan administram las manieyras de curacio en alcunas malautias, e aquelas medicinas no conferieysso, e aprop en la fi de la causa aministra hom cauteri, e aprofieyta ad aquela.	And the reason for this is to the contrary of what you think; the idea that cautery is the last resort of medicine does not mean that it is used as a final option after all other methods of healing have failed. Rather, it means that when administering various treatments for certain illnesses, if those medicines do not bring about improvement, then cautery is used at the end of the treatment process and proves to be effective.
E lahoras de aqui cat16 que cauteri es le derier remezi de medicina, no segon la entencio la qual entendo les vulgars e trops dels fols metges.	And so from this it is clear that cautery is the last resort of medicine, but not in the way that the common people and foolish doctors understand it.
E diyssero les antics que cauteri am aur es milhor que cauteri am ferr, e no diyssero aquo sino per la equalitat del aur e sublimitat de la sua sustancia.	The ancients said that cautery using gold is better than cautery using iron, and they did not say this without reason. They believed that the equality and sublime nature of gold made it a superior choice for cautery.
E diyssero que le loc de cauteri no fa brac, cum aquo no sia absolutament vertat, quar yeu ja he aquo proat e he atrobat que aquel no fa aquo sino en alcus cors ses les autres, e cauteri am aquel es bo e milhor que am ferr ayssi quo els diyssero; mays empero quan tu fas cauteri am foc am de aur, no es a tu declarat, quar es egnit segon la quantitat que tu vols per la rugor de l’aur, e quar prepara a recebre freg; e si ajustas sobre lu ignicio se fon l’aur per le foc, e caso en le foc alcunas laminas per que le artifex catz per la occupacio de aquel.	The ancients said that the location of cautery does not cause scarring, but this is not an absolute truth, for I have proven and found that it is not always the case. Cautery using gold can be good and better than iron as they said, but when performing cautery with a gold fire, it is not clearly stated how much heat should be used, as it depends on the desired level of heat for the procedure. Gold must be heated to a high temperature in order to burn, which can cause scorching or even melting if the fire is too hot. This can result in the loss of some of the gold due to its melting point being lower than that of iron.
E per aquo es fayt cauteri am ferr deves nos pus leugerament e pus propdanament a rectitut de operacio.	And so, cautery is performed using iron because it should be done lightly and precisely in order to achieve the desired result.
E yeu ja he ordenat aquest capitol en le cauteri segon capitols, et he ordenat aquels del cap entro les pes, per so que aleugo le demandant aquo que vol de lu.	I have now organized this chapter on cautery as I have done with other chapters, and have placed the head within the feet in order to lighten the burden of your questioning.
De cauteri de dolor de cap per frigiditat e humiditat.	On using cautery to treat pain caused by cold and wet complexion in the head.
Le capitol primier.	The first chapter.
Aquesta cauterizacio confereys a la humiditat e frigiditat sobre le servel accident de la qual so doas causas, so es causa de soda e multitut de flux raumatic, apelat corissa, del cap a las partidas dels huelhs e de las aurelhas fluent, e multitut de dormir, e de dolor de dentz e del guolayro, e universalment de tota malautia que ve per fregiditat, ayssi cum paraliticament, sodo e apoplexio, e semblantz en aquelas malautias.	This cauterization is used to treat the humidity and coldness of the head, which are the causes of various symptoms such as chronic runny nose, called coryza, from the head down to the ears and eyes, excessive sleepiness, toothaches, jaw pain, and generally all illnesses caused by coldness, such as paralysis, gout, and apoplexy, among others.
La forma de aquesta cauterizacio es aquesta, que primieyrament comandes al malaute que sia evacuat am medicina lacsativa le cap mondificant, per tres o per quatre nueytz, segon que exhigeys la vertut del malaute e la edat de lu e la sua costuma.	The method for this type of cauterization is as follows: first, the patient must be evacuated using a purgative medicine to cleanse the head, for three or four nights, depending on the severity of the illness, the age and habits of the patient.
E aprop comanda li que raza le sieu cap am razor, e aprop fay aquel sezer entre las tuas mas sobre una banca cayrada e que pause las suas mas sobre le pietz sieu.	And then you should command the patient to shave their head with a razor, and have them sit on a raised bench with their hands resting on their chest.
E aprop pausa la razit de la tua palma aprop le pous sobre la razit del nas entre les huels sieus.	Then you should place the edge of your palm over the patient's nose, between their eyes.
Mays empero, cum le tieu dit del mieg loc es pervengut, signa aquel loc am tenta, e aprop igneys le cauteri olivar del qual aquesta es la forma:	But when the desired location has been reached, mark it with ink, and then heat the olive wood cautery, which should be shaped as follows:
E aprop pausa aquel sobre le loc senhat am tenta, a manieyra que descent, am la qual la tieua ma sia constrengida petit a petit, e tu revolveys aquel.	Then place the cautery over the marked location and press down gently, causing the skin to slowly contract as you rotate it.
E aprop leva la tua ma leugerament e reguarda le loc, e si veses ja del os esser descubert alcuna quantitat del cap, ayssi cum la quantitat de gra de errs, lahoras eleva la tua ma, e si no torno la tua ma am aquel ferr, am autre de aquel, si es enfrigidat, entro que sia vist del os aquo que yeu he dit a tu.	And then you should slowly lift your hand and check the area for any signs of exposed bone, such as the size of a grain of barley. If so, apply more pressure with the cautery until you see the desired result. If it becomes too cold, use another heated cautery in its place. [1]
E aprop pren un petit de sal e disolveys aquel sobre le loc e leyssa aquel per tres jorns.	Then take a pinch of salt and dissolve it over the area, leaving it in place for three days.
E aprop pausa sobre lu coto enbegut en boder e leyssa aquel sobre lu entro que sia destrusida la scara del foc.	Then apply a compress soaked in egg white to the area and leave it in place until the burn scar has healed.
E aprop cura le loc am anguent tetrafarmacon entro que sia sanat.	And then care for the wound with tetrapharmacum ointment until it has healed.
E ja diyssero que quant la plagua roman uberta, tant mielhs geta le brac, per que es milhor e mays juvatiu.	And they said that when the wound remains open, it heals better and is more beneficial, for this method is better and more curative.
E diyssero alcus de lor que sia cauterizada la codena entro al os, e sia tengut le cauteri entro que sia adhurida alcuna partida de la specitut del os.	And some of them said that the shoulder blade should be cauterized right up to the bone, and the cautery should be left in place until it becomes attached to a portion of the bone.
E aprop sia ras aquo que es adhust del os, e aprop sia curat.	Then scrape off what is attached to the bone and care for the wound.
E diyssero autres que am lo cauteri pervengua al derier, entro que enprema en le os forta enprecio entro que le os caga, e aquesta es la forma de alphecati petit:	And others said that the cautery should reach the spine, causing deep penetration into the bone until it causes severe pain, and this is the form of the alphecatic procedure:
E estiman de aquel loc expiran la vapors del cap.	And they believe that this location is where the vapors of the head are released.
E sia tenguda la plagua uberta per lonc temps, e aprop sia curada entro que sia consolidada.	The wound should be left open for a long time and cared for until it has healed and become solid.
Mays a mi no so vistas aquestas doas specias de cauteri de tot, sino en alcus homes segon via de temor; e layssa aquel, deves mi, milhor es am salut, quan es; quar le cap es develitat per solucio de continuitat de lu ayssi cum havem testificat en les autres membres, e majorment quan le cap del malaute es de freul natura.	But I have not seen these two types of cautery performed on all patients, but only in certain cases due to fear; it is better to leave it alone if possible, as the head is more vulnerable due to the lack of continuity in its structure, especially when the patient has a weak constitution.
E la specia de cauteri primieyra es mays salva e milhor deves mi; e de aquela husi e am aquela obra am salut.	And I believe that the first type of cautery is safer and better, and this method should be used with care for the patient's well-being.
Capitol segon.	The second chapter.
Del cauteri del cap.	On cauterization of the head.
Quan en tot le cap accideys dolor cronica e longua e aquo es en le malaute prolonguat, e usa de gerras e de cochias e de capipurges e de emplaustres e de guatz e de cadels e de gualinas e de semblantz, e majorment si ja es cauterizat am un cautere le qual recontam e no aprofieyta a lu deguna de aquelas causas, lahoras considera quar si le cap del malaute es de fort creacio en la sua natura; e no es freul et atroba mot gran freg, lahoras aquel cauterisa am autra cauteri dejos aquel un pauc.	When a chronic and long-lasting pain occurs in the entire head, and various treatments such as gears, cossacks, capillaries, emplasters, poultices, plasters, leeches, blisters, and similar remedies have been used without success, especially if the patient has already undergone cauterization with one cautery that did not bring any relief. Consider whether the patient's head is of a strong nature and not weak, and if there is significant swelling, then use another type of cautery, but only lightly.
E aprop cauterisa aquel sobre le corn del sieu cap am cauteri entro que la codena es partida.	And then cauterize the patient's head above the ear using a cautery that divides the shoulder blade.
Incisa la codena e sia descuberta del os la quantitat la qual havem recontat e cauteriza aquel am un cauteri en la partida deriera del cap en le loc le qual es apelat vas, — e es aquel loc en le qual es pausada ventosa.	Cut the shoulder blade and expose the amount of bone that we have indicated, then cauterize it with a cautery in the back of the head at the location called the "vas", which is where a cup is placed for bloodletting.
Et alleuja la tua ma en aysso, e no descobras le os, quar le malaute per aquo atroba mot gran dolor diversa de la dolor de totz les autres cauteris del cap.	And be gentle in doing this, do not expose the bone, as it can cause significant pain to the patient, different from that of other head cauterizations.
E yeu diyre aquest cauteri en son loc, quar cove que·l cauteri am le qual so cauterisatz les corns del cap e le occiput es pus subtil cauteri que aquel am le qual es cauterisat le mieg loc del cap; e aquesta es la forma de lu.	I recommend this type of cautery in its place, as it is more subtle than the one used for the corn of the head and the occiput, and here is its shape:
Capitol ters.	The third chapter.
De cauterisacio de emigranea no-antiqua.	On the use of cautery for non-ancient migraines.
Quan endeve en la partida del cap dolor sodo, o es stenduda dolor entro al uelh, sia evacuat am medicinas le cap mondificantz, e sia aministrada l’autra curacio, la qual yeu he dita en las devesios de las malautias; e tot no aprofieyta, lahoras cauterisacio en lu es en dos manieyras: o cauterisacio am medicina acuta comburent, o am ferr.	When there is pain in the side of the head or a throbbing pain that extends to the eye, the patient should be evacuated using purifying medicines for the head and other treatments as I have described earlier for various illnesses. If these methods do not bring relief, then cauterization may be performed in two ways: either with a burning medicine or with iron.
Mays cauteri am medicina comburent es que tu prenguas una dolsa de alh, e escorgas aquela e abcindas las extremitatz de lu de amdos les caps.	Cauterization using a burning medicine is performed by taking a piece of aloe, cutting it open and cauterizing the ends of both sides with fire.
E aprop incideys le loc de la dolor en la templa am una lanceta lada entro que sia en lu feyt loc dejos la codena, entro que sia occultada.	And then make an incision in the location of the pain at the temple with a sharp lancet until it reaches the shoulder blade and is hidden from sight.
E aprop strenh sobre lu am stopada per descent constreccio, e layssa aquel per le spazi de tres horas; e aprop deslia le e tratz le alh, e laysa la plagua per dos o per tres jorn, e aprop pausa sobre lu coto submergit en boder entro que le loc fassa brac.	Then apply pressure to the incision with a stopper for gentle compression and leave it in place for three hours; then remove the aloe and leave the wound open for two or three days, and then apply a compress soaked in egg white until the wound heals.
E aprop cura aquel am enguent entro que sia sanat.	And then care for the wound with ointment until it has healed.
E si tu voys, fe aquo am alcunas medicinas comburentz las quals yeu he scriutas en le douse tractat de medicinas comburentz.	And if you wish, do that with some flammable medications which I have written in the two treatises on flammable medications.
Mays la cauterisacio am ferr segon aquesta manieyra: igneys per cauteri del qual aquesta es la forma:	But let cauterization with iron be performed in this manner: the shape of the iron for cauterizing is as follows:
e es apelat claus clavilhs, quar le cap de lu es ayssi cum forma de clavel en le qual es alcuna curvitat, e·n le mieg loc de lu es eminensia petita.	and it is called a nail-shaped cautery, because the end of it has the shape of a nail with some curvature, and in the middle of it is a small raised area.
E aprop pausa sobre loc de la dolor, e rete la tua ma — per que no sia adhurida la arceria la qual es dejos — e revol le ferr petit a petit am velocitat.	Then place it on the site of pain and hold your hand so that the sinew behind it is not burned, and slowly rotate the iron repeatedly.[1](footnote: The original text uses "arceria" which I translated as "sinew", but in modern medical terminology, this term could also refer to an artery. In either case, the meaning of the sentence is clear: hold your hand so that the underlying tissue is not burned.)
E si la quantitat de lu que es adhurida per la specitut de la codena ayssi quo la maytat de lu, e elava la tua ma per so que la arteria no sia adhurida la qual es dejos, per so que no vengua flux de sanc.	And if the amount of tissue burned by the tip of the cautery is as much as the size of it, raise your hand so that the underlying artery is not burned which is behind, to prevent bleeding.
E aprop enbibeys coto en aygua de sal e pausa aquel sobre le loc, e layssa aquel per tres dias; e aprop pausa coto mulhat am boder, e aprop cura am enguent entro que sia sanat.	Then soak a piece of cloth in saltwater and place it on the area, leaving it there for three days; then apply a piece of cloth smeared with mud, and treat it with ointment until it is healed.[1](footnote: The original text uses "coto" which could refer to any type of fabric or bandage. I assumed that it refers to a separate piece of cloth in each instance since the first application is soaked in saltwater and then removed, while the second one is smeared with mud and left on until healing occurs.)
E si voys, cauterisa am la extremitat del cutellari segon cauteri, e guarda te de incisio de arteria en aquesta emigranea propriament no-antiqua.	And if you wish, cauterize the end of the stylet in the manner of cautery, and be careful not to cut an artery in this non-ancient emigration (i.e., modern times).[1](footnote: The word "emigranea" is not a standard medical term in Latin or any Romance language. It appears that the author is using it to refer to the practice of cauterization, which may have been considered outdated in their time.)
Capitol quart.	Chapter Four.[1](footnote: The original text uses "Capitol" which is Latin for "chapter." I assumed this was a heading for a new section of the text, and translated it as such.)
De cauterizacio d’emigranea antiqua.	On the cauterization of ancient (or outdated) emigration.[1](footnote: The word "emigranea" is not a standard medical term in Latin or any Romance language. It appears that the author is using it to refer to the practice of cauterization, which may have been considered outdated in their time.)
Quan tu curas emigranea am aquo que havem dit de la curacio precedent, e aquo que havem dit en las divisios de las malautias, e no aprofieyta la curacio, e vezes per la malautia que no abasta a lu aquo que havem dit del primier cauteri am medicina o del cauteri am foc, lahoras cove que tu igniscas le cauteri cutellar entro que sia albificat, pus que significas sobre le loc de la dolor am linha de longuesa de la qual sia la maytat del dit, o quays aquel; e depausa la tua ma per una veguada e strenh aquela entro incidiscas la arceria e pervengua entro al os.	When you treat emigranea with what we have said in the previous treatment and what we have said in the divisions of diseases, and the treatment does not work, and sometimes due to the disease it is not enough for what we have said about the first cautery with medicine or with fire, then it is necessary to heat the scalpel cautery until it turns white, because this means that you are applying it on the site of pain with a line of length equal to the width of your finger, or smaller. Then place your hand firmly and strongly, so that you can incise the artery and reach the bone.
Empero necessari es a tu que guardes de la continuacio de la mandibula, la qual es mauguda deves la masticacio, e que le lacert no sia adhurit e le nervi le qual mau aquela, e que no s’endevengua espasme.	However, it is necessary for you to be careful not to damage the continuation of the mandible, which can be harmed by chewing, and not to burn the ligament that moves it, or the nerves that control it, and not to cause spasm.[1](footnote: The original text uses "mandibula" which is Latin for "mandible," the lower jawbone. I assumed this was a reference to the entire jaw structure, including surrounding muscles and ligaments.)
E si es sobre la custodia e cautela de flux de sanc de l’arteria que es abciza, quar en la abcizio de lu es temor, e majorment ad aquel le qual ignora aquo que fa e no es studios e esproat; e layssa la operacio en lu al comensament.	And if it is about the care and caution in preventing bleeding from the cut artery, which is a concern during cutting, especially for those who are not knowledgeable about what they are doing and lack experience. Let the operation be left to someone with more expertise.[1](footnote: The original text uses "abcizio" which is Latin for "cutting." I assumed this was a reference to surgical incision, particularly in relation to cutting an artery.)
E yeu vindre am rememoracio del regiment de flux de sanc accident de la arceria segon la sieua manieyra, en le sieu loc de aquest libre.	And I will come with a reminder of the regimen for bleeding from an artery based on its manner, in its place in this book.[1](footnote: The original text uses "regiment" which is Latin for "regimen." I assumed this was a reference to a set of guidelines or instructions for managing bleeding from an artery.)
E si veses de aquesta malautia que no abaste aquest cauteri e veses le cors del malaute tollerable, cauteriza aquel en le mieg loc del cap ayssi cum havem recontat, e cura la plagua entro que sia sanada.	And if you see that this illness is not alleviated by this cautery and the patient's body can tolerate it, then cauterize the middle of the head in the same way as we have described before, and treat the wound until it is healed.[1](footnote: The original text uses "cors" which is Latin for "body." I assumed this was a reference to the patient's overall health and ability to tolerate further treatment.)
E si voys, aministra le cauteri le qual havem dit en le capitol de streccio de arceria am cauteri havent dos cotels, e es milhor cauterizacio aquesta e mays conferent.	And if you wish, administer the cautery that we described in the chapter on stretching of the artery with cautery having two scalpels, and this is better and more effective cauterization.[1](footnote: The original text uses "aministra" which is Latin for "administer." I assumed this was a reference to performing or carrying out the procedure.)
Capitol .v.	Chapter Five.[1](footnote: The original text uses "Capitol" which is Latin for "chapter." I assumed this was a heading for a new section of the text, and translated it as such.)
De cauterisacio de las dolors de aurelhas.	On the cauterization of ear pain.[1](footnote: The original text uses "aurelhas" which is Latin for "ears." I assumed this was a reference to pain in the ears and translated it as such.)
Quan en la aurelha ve dolor per freg e es curat am causas lacsativas e am l’autra curacio la qual he dita en la divisio, e no es remauguda la dolor, lahoras igneys le cauteri, e es aquest le qual ha nom puncta, del qual aquesta es la forma:	When there is pain in the ear due to cold and it is treated with purgatives and other treatments as I have mentioned in the division (of diseases), but the pain persists, then cauterize with a pointed cautery, which has the name puncta, and its shape is as follows: [1](footnote: The original text uses "freg" which is Latin for "cold." I assumed this was a reference to cold weather or temperature causing ear pain.)
E aprop puncta aprop la ignicio, e sia menat al enviro de tota la aurelha ayssi cum roda es revolguda, o en le circuit de quascuna essemps si la dolor es en quascuna.	Then place the pointed cautery near the fire and rotate it around the entire ear like a wheel or in the circumference of each part if the pain is in a specific area.[1](footnote: The original text uses "roda" which is Latin for "wheel." I assumed this was a reference to circular motion, as if the cautery were being rotated around the ear.)
Alonga te am le cauteri de la razit de la aurelha pauc a pauc pus que aias senhat le loc am tenta.	Approach the cautery slowly towards the ridge of the ear, gradually increasing pressure until you feel that the area has been marked by the heat.[1](footnote: The original text uses "razit" which is Latin for "ridge." I assumed this was a reference to the outer edge or ridge of the ear where it meets the head.)
E si le cauteri de detz puntz en tota aurelha, e quays aquela, e aprop cura les locz entro que sian sanatz.	And if you perform cauterization with ten points on the entire ear, and then treat the areas with ointment until they are healed.[1](footnote: The original text uses "detz puntz" which is Occitan for "ten points." I have assumed that this refers to a form of cauterization using ten separate points or marks, as might be made with a multi-pointed instrument.)
Capitol .vi.	Chapter Six.[1](footnote: The text appears to use "Capitol" which is Latin for "chapter." I have translated it as such, assuming that this is a heading for a new section of the text.)
De cauterizacio de turtura.	On the Cautery of Tumors.[1](footnote: The original text uses "turtura" which is Occitan for "tumor." I have translated it as such, assuming that this refers to a growth or swelling on the body.)
Turtura la qual es curada e am cauterizacio no es sino de las specias las quals veno per flecma, segon que havem dit en las divisios de las malautias.	A tumor that has been cured and only requires cauterization of the species that come through abscesses, as we have mentioned in the divisions of diseases.[1](footnote: The original text uses "flecma" which is Occitan for "abscess." I have translated it as such, assuming that this refers to a localized collection of pus.)
Esquiva cauterizacio de la specia que endeve per siccacio o per spasme del nervi.	Avoid cauterization of the species that develop due to dryness or spasm of the nerves.[1](footnote: The original text uses "specia" which is Latin for "seed," but in this context I have translated it as "species" to refer to small growths or deposits. The text also uses "endeve" which is Occitan for "develop." I have translated it as such, assuming that this refers to the formation of abscesses due to dryness or spasm of the nerves.)
Quan tu curas aquela specia de turtura am jerras e capipurgi e guarguarismes, e no comfereys la tua curacio, lahoras cove que tu cauterizas le malaute am tres cauteris: la i deves la razit de la aurelha, e·l segon un petit dejos le sieu templar, e le ters deves la conjunccio de doas labias.	When you treat that species of tumor with geraniums and caper spurge and wormwood, and your treatment is not effective, then it is necessary to cauterize the patient with three cauteries: the first on the ridge of the ear, the second a little below the temple, and the third at the junction of the two lips.[1](footnote: The original text uses "gerra" which is Occitan for "geranium," "capipurgi" which is Latin for "caper spurge," and "guarguarismes" which is Occitan for "wormwood." I have translated these as such, assuming that they are being used as herbal remedies to treat the tumor. The text also uses "comfereys" which is Occitan for "comfort" or "alleviate." I have translated it as such, assuming that this means the treatment was not effective if the patient did not experience relief from their symptoms.)
E pausa lo tieu cauteri per le contrari de la partida malauta, quar mollificacio no ve sino en la partida que apar sana.	And place your cautery on the opposite side of the affected area, because softening does not occur until after healing has begun on the visible surface.[1](footnote: The original text uses "partida" which is Occitan for "side." I have translated it as such, assuming that this refers to a specific location or direction. The text also uses "mollificacio" which is Latin for "softening." I have translated it as such, assuming that this refers to the healing process and relief of symptoms caused by the tumor.)
E la forma de cauterisacio es que cauterizas aquel am le cauteri en le dreyt de la extremitat de la aurelha pus sobirana un petit sobre le corn del cap, e en le templar autre, la longuesa del qual sia segon la longitut del dit pous, e depausa la tua ma am cauteri entro que sia comburida la quantitat de la maytat de la specitut de la codena.	And the form of cauterization is to cauterize that spot on the right side of the uppermost part of the ear lobe, about a small distance above the crown of the head, and in the meantime, the length of which should be according to the length of the finger, and then place your hand with the cautery until it is burnt to the extent of the size of the spot of the cancer.
E aquesta es la forma del cauteri, e es specia del cutellari, la forma del qual es denant mesa.	And this is the form of the cautery, and it is a tool of the cutler, the shape of which is in front of the table.
Mays empero pus subtil es que aquel un pauc ayssi co vesas; e cove que cotel en lu de superflua groceza un pauc.	However, more subtly, it is somewhat similar to a knife; and it is necessary that the knife be thinner than its excessive thickness.
E aprop cura le loc am aquo que es denant procezit entro que sia sanat.	Then heal the place with what has been processed beforehand until it is healed.
Capitol .vii.	Chapter 7.
De cauterizacio de apoplextia antiqua.	On the ancient method of cauterization for apoplexy.
Quan apoplextia es antiquada e curas aquela am aquo que havem dit e no confereys la tua medicacio e le malaute no ha febre, lahoras cauteriza aquel am quatre cauteris: sobre totz les corn del sieu cap; e am cauteri e le mieg loc del cap, ayssi cum havem dit; e am cauteri en le coguot.	When apoplexy is ancient and healed with what we have said and you do not consider the medicine for the patient without fever, then cauterize that person with four cauteries: mainly on the crowns of their head; and with a cautery in the middle of the forehead, as we have said; and with a cautery on the nape.
E la manieyra del cauteri es fayta segon que es desus dit.	And the method of cauterization is done according to what has been said above.
E ja es cauterizat sobre la boca del estomac; e es mays derier; e aprop sia curat am aquo que procezeys.	And it has been cauterized above the mouth of the stomach, and it is more posterior; then let it be healed with what you have prepared.
Capitol .viii.	Chapter 8.
De cauterizacio de obblivio fayta per flacma.	On the method of cauterization for forgetfulness caused by flame.
Cove que sian donatz al malaute en le comensament jerras grans e pilulas le servel mondificantz.	It is necessary that large jars and purifying pills be given to the patient at the beginning.
E aprop ras le cap tot del malaute e pausa sus le coguot de lu emplaustre de cetre descrit en le tractat dels emplastres.	Then shave the entire head of the patient and place on the nape an ointment of incense described in the treatise on ointments.
E pausa aquel alcunas veguadas, quar aquel es manieyra de cauteri.	And place that several times, for that is a method of cauterization.
E fay aquo segon aquel meteys orde le qual ja he dit.	And do that in the same order which I have already said.
E donc si per aqueles sanat bo es; e sino, lahoras fay a lu tres cauteris en la deriera partida de sieu cap, les quals sian deysendentz de la partida pus sobirana del cap entro a la partida pus dejos del col.	And so, if they are healed well by that, otherwise then make three cauteries in the back of their head, which should descend from the uppermost part of the head to the lowest part of the neck.
E pausa entre quascun cauteri la grossetut del dit, e aprop cura lo cauteri am aquo que es procedit.	And place between each cautery the width of a finger, and then heal the cauterization with what has been prepared.
Mays si tu vos addicio e le malaute es aquo tollerant, lahoras fay a lu cauteri en le mieg loc; e si voys major addicio, lahora cauteriza aquel sobre les dos corns.	But if you see that the patient can tolerate more, then make a cautery in the middle of their head; and if they can tolerate even more, then cauterize on both sides of their head.
Aprop cura aquel entro que sia sanat; e sia le cauteri olivar segon la forma denant donat.	Then heal that until it is healed, and let the cauteries be olive-shaped according to the form given previously.
Capitol .ix.	Chapter 9.
De cauterisacio de parazili e de mollificacio de tot le cors.	On the method of cauterization for paralysis and softening of the entire body.
Cove que tu procesiscas en mondificacio del cap am jerras e am aquo que havem dit; e aprop ras le cap del malaute, e aprop cauteriza aquel am cauteri en le mieg loc del cap, e am cauteri sobre totz les corns del cap, e am cauteri sobre la deriera partida de lu, e am tres cauteris sobre les spondils del col.	It is necessary that you prepare for the purification of the head with jars and what has been mentioned; then shave the patient's head and cauterize them with a cautery in the middle of their forehead, and on both sides of their head, and on the nape, and with three cauteries on the vertebrae of their neck.
E si es necessari en la malautia de mollificacio del cors de trops aquel e les malautes tollerantz e la malautia es fort, lahoras cauteriza aquel am quatre cauteris sobre les spondils del dos, e dererament am cauteri entro que sia comborit de la codena mot de lu, e aleva la tieua ma.	And if it is necessary in the illness of softening of the body due to too much moisture and the patient can tolerate more and the illness is severe, then cauterize them with four cauteries on the vertebrae of their back, and especially with a cautery inside where the cancer has spread significantly, and raise your hand.
E aprop cura aquel entro que sia sanat, e aquest sia cauteri olivar.	Then heal that until it is healed, and let this be an olive-shaped cautery.
Capitol .x.	Chapter 10.
De cauterisacio de epilemcia.	On the method of cauterization for epilepsy.
No es cauterizat le epilemtic sino aquella epilemcia es per flecma.	An epileptic is not cauterized, except when epilepsy is caused by flame.
E donc cove que mondifiques le cervel de lu al comensament de lu am yeras e am l’autra curacio la qual havem dicta en la divisio quan le malaute es gran e es tollerant la exceperacio de las medicinas.	Therefore, it is necessary to purify the brain of the patient at the beginning with jars and with the other cure which we have mentioned in the division when the patient is severe and can tolerate an exception to the medications.
E si es enfant le qual no sufferte las medicinas, lahoras aministra guarguarissmes e mastiguatoris le servel mondifican, denant aquo per motz dias, am bonifficacio de las viandas.	And if it is a child who cannot tolerate medications, then administer laxatives and chewable medicines for purification, beforehand for several days, with the improvement of their diet.
E aprop ras le cap del malaute, e aprop cauteriza aquel am un cauteri en le mieg loc del cap segon la manieyra precedent, e am autre cauteri en le occiput de lu, e sobre quascun corn del cap sieu cauterisa.	Then shave the head of the patient and cauterize them with a single cautery in the middle of their forehead according to the previous method, and with another cautery on the nape of their neck, and above each ear should be cauterized.
E si le malaute es fort e es tollerant, lahoras cauteriza aquel am cauteris les quals he ditz, en havent paraliticament e mollificacio del cors sobre les spondils del col e les spondils del dos.	And if the patient is severe and can tolerate more, then cauterize them with several cauteries, as I have said, having paralysis and softening of the body on the vertebrae of their neck and back.
E sia cauteri olivar segon qu’es precedit.	And let the cauteries be olive-shaped as described earlier.
Mays si le malaute es enfant, lahoras pausa cauteri subtil segon aquesta manieyra.	But if the patient is a child, then place subtle cauteries according to this method.
Capitol .xi.	Chapter 11. [https://www.deepl.com/translator#auto/en/De+cauterisacio+de+paralisis+de+la+manya+\(manieyra+antiqua\).](https://www.deepl.com/translator#auto/en/De%20cauterisacio%20de%20paralisis%20de%20la%20manya%20%5C(manieyra%20antiqua%5C)%.29)
De cauterizacio de melencolia.	On the method of cauterization for melancholy.
Quan las causas de melencolia so humiditatz corrompudas e flacma gros, lahoras cauteriza aquel am les cauteris les quals havem ditz en le havent paralisi.	When the causes of melancholy are corrupt humidity and coarse flame, then cauterize with the cauteries that I have mentioned in treating paralysis.
E si la causa de melencolia es superfluitat declinant a melencolia, e le cors del malaute es humit, lahoras da ha beure aquo que mundifica le cervel de lu segon aquo que ha precedut en la divisio.	And if the cause of melancholy is an excess tending toward melancholy, and the patient's body is humid, then give them to drink what purifies their brain according to what has been mentioned earlier in the section.
E aprop ras le cap del malaute, e aprop fay tortora decentment fayta de li sobre le cercle, e aprop depausa aquela en le mieg loc del cap.	Then shave the patient's head and place a well-made wick of linen on their crown, then place it in the middle of their forehead.
E le malaute sia sesent cayrat, e sia tengut de tota partida.	And let the patient be 60 years old and held in high esteem by all.
E aprop pausa liniment; et es pus digne de boder antic de ovelhas.	Then apply a linen cloth, which is more worthy of ancient sheep's wool.
E escalfa aquel sobre le foc per calefaccio temprada per mesura, le qual le dit sufferta quan es mes en lu.	And warm that on the fire with moderate heat, which the patient can tolerate when it is placed on them.
E aprop vuo’ aquel en le mieg loc del cap de lu en le cercle, e leysa lu entro que sia enfregidat.	Then place that in the middle of their forehead on the crown and leave it there until it has cooled down.
E fay aquo am le malaute en tota semmana una veguada, am le autre regiment de lu bo entro que sia sanat; o si vols, cauteriza aquel fazen petitz puntz segon lo mays de lu, sino que tenguas la ma am un cauteri ayssi ordenat: aquesta es specia de cauteri la qual humecta le cervel am equalitat.	And do this with the patient every week once, along with their other good regimen until they are healed; or if you wish, perform small punctures according to their needs, but keep your hand steady holding a cautery in this way: this is a type of cautery that moistens the brain equally.
E aprop pausa aquel coto enbegut en boder o en grays de gualina.	Then apply a piece of leather soaked in linen or wool cloth.
Capitol .xii.	Chapter 12.
De cauterisacio de aygua descendent en le huel.	On the method of cauterization for water that is accumulating in the joints.
Quan a tu es declarat le comensament de aygua en le huel per les senhals les quals yeu he ditz en la divisio, lahoras comensa e dona en beure al malaute aquo que mondifique le cap de lu, e guarda aquel de totas humiditatz.	When you have recognized the onset of water in the joints by the signs that I have mentioned earlier in the section, then begin and give the patient to drink what purifies their head, and keep them away from all moisture.
E fay aquel suzar en banh en degu per alcus jorns.	And make them sweat in a bath for several days.
E aprop comanda a lu que raza le sieu cap, e cauteriza aquel am cauteri en le mieg loc del cap; e aprop cauteriza aquel am dos cauteris sobre dos templas si es le comensament de ysement de aygua en dos huels, o de la un latz si es comensamen de l’aygua en un huel.	Then command the patient to shave their head and cauterize them in the middle of their forehead with a single cautery; and also cauterize them above both temples if it is the beginning of water in both joints, or on one side if it is the beginning of fluid build-up in one joint.
Incideys am cauteri totas las venas e arcerias las quals so dejos la codena; e sian les cauteris en aquela lonh en la latitut de las templas.	Incise with a cautery all the veins and arteries that are below the spine, and let the cauteries be in that location at the width of the temples.
E guarda te de fluxs de sanc quan es cauterizat; e si veses de lu fluxs de sanc, osta le am alcuna medicina, la qual es a tu possible.	And be careful not to cause any bleeding when cauterizing; and if you see that there is bleeding, then stop it with some medicine that is available to you.
E yeu vindre am savieza la qual es en extraccio de arcerias e am abscizio de aquelas e cautela de fluxs de sanc.	And I will come with wisdom in the extraction of arteries, and in cutting out that which is necessary, and carefulness to prevent bleeding.
E alcunas vetz es cauterizat en le cervitz dejos dos osses am dos cauteris dererament produzitz.	And sometimes it is necessary to cauterize the neck below two bones with two properly produced cauteries.
Capitol .xiii.	Chapter 13.
De cauterizacio de lacrimas antiquas.	On the method of cauterization for ancient tears.
Quan lacrimas dels huels so antiquas assuduament e per las venas e arterias las quals so en le loc manifest del cap defora e es verificat que aquo es superfluitatz frejas flecmatiquas, lahoras cauteriza aquel am cauteri le qual havem recontat en le capitol de comensament de aygua cazent en les huels, e am cauteri en le mieg loc del cap e am dos cauteris en la cervitz dejos dos templas, e am dos cauteris en la cervitz dejos dos osses.	When the tears from the eyes are ancient and due to the veins and arteries that are in the manifest location on the outside of the head, and it is confirmed that this is excessive and caused by dry, flaming heat, then cauterize with the cautery that we have mentioned in the chapter on water accumulating in the joints, and also in the middle of the forehead, and above both temples, and below two bones in the neck.
E si indigeyses de addicio, lahoras cauteriza aquel en tot latz de la coa del huel sobre la extremitat del sobrecilh am petit cauteri.	And if necessary, then also cauterize at the outer edge of the leg on the upper eyelid with a small cautery.
Capitol .xiiii.	Chapter 14
De cauterizacio de fetor de nas.	On cauterization for nasal foul smell.
Quan tu medicas aquel am aquo que havem dit en la divisio e no aprofieyta la tua medicacio, lahoras tu aparelha e dona en beure al malaute las cochias per tres noytz; e aprop ras le cap de lu, e cauteriza le am cauteri migier am cauteri olivar.	When you treat that which we have mentioned in the division and your treatment is not effective, then prepare and give to the patient to drink for three nights the broths, and shave his head, and cauterize him with a medium-sized, olive-shaped cautery on the head.
E aprop cauteriza aquel am cauteri clavelh am dos cauteris sobre les dos sobrecilhs dejos les cabels un petit.	And then cauterize with a nail-shaped cautery, with two cauteries, below the eyebrows, just above the hairline, in a small area.[translated by SummarizeBot]
E guarda te de la arceria que no incindas aquela.	And be careful not to damage the artery.
E del cauteri clavilh aquesta es la forma.	And this is the shape of the nail-shaped cautery.
Capitol .xv.	Chapter 15.
De cauteri de mollificacio de palpebras dels huels.	On cauterization for softening of eyelid swelling. [translated by SummarizeBot]
Quan la palpebra del huel es mollificada per malautia o per humiditat, lahoras cauteriza aquela palpebre1 am un cauteri am aquest cauteri lunar; e aquesta es la forma de lu:	When the eyelid is swollen due to illness or moisture, then cauterize that eyelid with a round-shaped cautery; and this is its shape: [translated by SummarizeBot]
E si vos, cauteriza aquel sobre les dos sobrecils un petit am dos cauteris en tota partida, e sian elonguatz de las timporas.	And if you do so, cauterize on both eyebrows in a small area with two cauteries, extending from the temples.
E sia la longitut de quascun cauteri segon la quantitat del sobrecil.	And let the length of each cautery be according to the size of the eyebrow.
E no premas trop la tua ma am le cauteri, mays segon la quantitat que la tersa partida de la palpebre sia adhurida.	And do not press too hard with your hand on the cautery, but only so that the upper third of the eyelid is affected.
Capitol .xvi.	Chapter 16. [translated by SummarizeBot]
De cauteri de la palpebre del huel quan les pels so convertitz a las partidas dedintz e punho le huel.	On cauterization for the eyelid when the eyelashes turn inward and poke the eye.
Quan les pels del huel son convertitz a las partidas dedintz ayssi que pungo le huel, cauteri en aquels es segon dos manieyras, quar cauteri o es am fer o es am medicina comburent.	When the eyelashes turn inward so that they poke the eye, there are two methods for cauterization: one is by fire and the other is through a burning medicine.
Si am cauteri de lu am foc, comanda al malaute denant aquo que leyse les sieus pels ayssi cum aquels les quals les mundan, entro que sian prolonguatz e engualhatz; e si punho aquel deves le lor naysement, lahoras tu strenh les huels de lu am una benda per so que no sia maugut entro que·ls pels sian nascutz.	If you perform cauterization by fire, order the patient to read aloud beforehand so that their eyes are open wide and free of obstructions, allowing them to stretch and clean the lashes; and if they poke the eye, then strengthen the eyelids with a bandage until the lashes have grown back. [translated by SummarizeBot]
Donc cum siran nascutz e engualhatz, lahoras pausa le cap del malaute en le tieu se, e aprop senha sobre la palpebre dels huels de lu am tenta, am senhal le qual sia segon la figura de fulha de merta, e sia le comensament del senhal prop dels pels.	When the lashes have grown back and are clean, then place the patient's head on your knee, and make a mark over the eyelid using your finger with a symbol that resembles a myrtle leaf, and let the beginning of the symbol be near the lashes.
E aprop pausa coto enbegut en album de huou o en mucillatge de ptilli sobre le huel.	And then place a small piece of lint soaked in egg white or paste made from psyllium over the eye. [translated by SummarizeBot]
E aprop igneys le cauteri del qual aquesta es la forma de lu.	Then heat up the cautery, which has this shape:
E aprop cauteriza sobre la figura la qual as senhada, petit a petit, em motas veguadas, entro que sia comburida la superficia de la codena la qual es ayssi cum fuelha de mirta, tota aparent propriament.	And then cauterize over the mark that you made, little by little, with steady movements, until the surface of the skin has been burned and resembles a myrtle leaf in appearance.
E senhal de sanetat de la tieua obra es que tu vegus la palpebre de l’huel ja esser contrayta e·ls pels de lu esser elevatz deves la punctura del huel.	The sign of healing from this procedure is if you see the eyelid contracted and the lashes lifted upwards near the puncture of the eye.
E donc eleva la tua ma e laysa aquel per tres jorns, e aprop pausa sobre lu coto am boder entro que sia eredicada la scara.	And then raise your hand and leave it there for three days, and place over the eye a piece of clean cloth until the scar has healed.
E aprop cura aquela am enguent entro que sia sanat.	And then care for the area with ointment until it is healed.
Mays si retorna per les pels alcuna causa aprop lor naysement e la palpebra es mollificada, lahoras fay autra vetz le cauteri sobre aquel tot ayssi cum avias fayt primieyrament.	But if the eyelashes turn inward again for some reason or the eyelid becomes swollen, then perform the cauterization once again just as you did before.
Mays si les pels so en la palpebra dejos, lahoras cauterisa aquela entro que sia elevada al sieu loc natural e sia engualhat e que les pels no punhan le huelh.	But if the lashes are on the eyelid instead of inside it, then perform the cauterization until the lashes are raised to their natural position and are clean and not poking the eye anymore.
Mays le cauteri am medicina comburent aquest es que comandes al malaute que leyse les pels entro que sian prolonguatz e engualhatz, e aprop sia fayta de carta de drap la forma de fuelha de mirtra.	But if you use a burning medicine as the cautery, then order the patient to read aloud to open their eyes wide and clean the lashes; and make a myrtle leaf-shaped piece of paper or cloth. [translated by SummarizeBot] [!translatorstop!] If using a caustic substance as the cautery, direct the patient to read aloud to widen their eyes and clean their lashes. Then create a myrtle leaf-shaped piece of paper or cloth.
E aprop pren de sabo conogut e de caus viva ana unc. .i., o quays aquo, e aprop mescle3 aquelas causas be, e fay aquo am festinacio per so que no sia enfregidat; e aprop expandeys de aquo sobre la carta la qual es fayta ayssi cum forma de fulha de mirtra, e pausa aquel sobre la un huel od amdos; e pausa dejos le huel coto enbegut en album de huou, e el cap del malaute sia en le tieu se.	And then take one ounce each of known soap and fresh wax. That is: Mix those substances quickly so that they do not harden, and spread some of the mixture over the paper shaped like a myrtle leaf, and place it over one or both eyes; and place a piece of clean cloth soaked in egg white under the eye, with the patient's head on your knee.
E pausa le dit sobre le medicina e prem aquela un petit e no la mauguas entro que lo malaute senta la mordicacio de la medicina, quar mordicacio es en lu ayssi cum de foc.	And place your finger over the medicine and press it slightly but not too hard until the patient feels a burning sensation, for this burning sensation is similar to that of fire.
E donc cum percevera aquo que el atrobo mordicacio, lahoras leyssa la medicina e mau aquela am le tieu dit; donc cum cessa la mordicacio, lahoras remau la medicina he lava le huel am aygua; e lahoras considera si vezes la palpebra ja es levada ayssi cum es lavada deves la costriccio am foc o am incisio, quar lahoras esta be; e si no torna sobre aquela de la medicina sobre le loc en le qual no ha empremut la medicina e no se denigra entro que sia engualhada la tua operacio e sia contrayt le huel.	And once the patient perceives this burning sensation, then remove your finger and let the medicine sit for a while; when the burning sensation ceases, then remove the medicine with your finger and rinse the eye with water. Then consider if the eyelid is raised as it should be due to the tightening from the fire or incision. If so, then it is good. But if not, reapply the medicine over the area where it has not yet been applied, and do not damage the operation until it heals and the eye contracts.[translated by SummarizeBot]
E aprop pausa sobre lu coto am boder entro que sia eradicada la codena de la adhustio, e aprop cura aquel am enguent deafinicon o am autre entro que sia sanat.	And then place over the eye a piece of clean cloth until the burn has healed; and after that, care for the area with a finishing ointment or another one until it is healed.
E es necessari a tu, deves la tua operacio que guardes am pervigil diligencia que en le huel no caia re de la medicina, e si la palpebre aprop alscus dias es mollificada e alcuna causa dels pels punh en le huel, lahoras itera la tua medicina sobre aquel loc le qual de la palpebre es mollificat, e propriamen ayssi quo as fayt al comensament, e aprop enaviro lu entro que sia sanat.	And it is important for you to carefully monitor your procedure to ensure that no residue of the medicine falls into the eye. If the eyelid becomes swollen for several days due to some reason and the lashes are poking the eye, then reapply the medicine over the area where the eyelid is swollen, just as you did at the beginning. And continue to monitor it until it heals.[translated by SummarizeBot]
E aquesta es la forma de fuelha de mirtra.	This is the shape of a myrtle leaf.
E sapias que les huels dels homes son diversificatz segon la magnitut e la parvitat, e donc segon aquo es fayta la tua contraccio.	And you should know that the eyes of men differ in size and smallness; therefore, adjust the tightening accordingly based on this.
E no sira amaguada la via de rectetut ad aquel al qual es studi en aquesta art.	And it is not right to hide the way of truth from one who studies in this art.
Capitol .xvii.	Chapter 17. [translated by SummarizeBot]
De cauterizacio de fistula que es en le lacrimal de l’huel.	On cauterization for a fistula in the tear duct of the eye. [translated by SummarizeBot]
Quan tu curas fistula am aquo que havem dit en las divisios de las malautias e no confereys la tua curacio, lahoras cove que tu cauterizas aquela segon aquesta manieyra: comanda al malaute que pause le cap sieu en le tieu se, e tengua le cap de lu alcun ministre entre las tieuas mas en tal manieyra que no sia maugut ni agitat am le sieu cap.	When you treat a fistula with what we have mentioned in the divisions of diseases and your treatment is not successful, then it is necessary for you to cauterize as follows: order the patient to place their head on your knee, and have a minister hold the patient's head between his thighs in such a way that it is neither harmed nor shaken by the patient's movements. [translated by SummarizeBot]
E aprop pausa coto enfus en album de huou o en mucellage de ptilli sobre le huel de lu.	And then place a piece of lint soaked in egg white or psyllium paste over the eye of the patient.
E aprop igneys le cauteri del qual aquesta es la forma:	And then heat up the cautery, which has this shape:
le qual sia conquau, ayssi cum es forma de cana o de pena de voltor, de la una extremitat am la qual es fayta lo cauteri.	which should be concave, with a shape like that of a reed or vulture's feather, at the end used for making the cautery.
E si voys, sia penetrant entro a la autra extremitat.	And if you wish, let it be penetrating at the other end.
E si vols sia sort ayssi cum tenta.	And if you want, let it have a handle like that of a spear. [translated by SummarizeBot]
Mays empero aquel que es concau es milhor a la tieua obra.	However, one that is concave is better for this procedure.
E aprop prem la fistula si es uberta, e tra de lu sania et exsicca aquela.	And then press the fistula if it is open, and extract pus from it and dry it out. [translated by SummarizeBot] [!translatorstop!] Heat up a concave cautery and press it against the open fistula to extract any pus or fluids and dry it out.
E si no es uberta, lahoras obre aquela e extratz la poyredura de lu.	And if it is not open, then make an incision in it and remove the pus from it. [translated by SummarizeBot]
E aprop pausa sobre lu le cauteri le qual sia be ignit, e te am aquel la tieua ma un petit deves le cauteri del huel a la partida del nas, per so que no erre la tua ma o le malaute sia enquietat, e lahoras pausa le cauteri en le grays del huel e corrompas aquel.	And then place the hot cautery over it, and hold the patient's eye with your other hand near the corner of the eye next to the nose, so that your hand does not shake or disturb the patient, and then apply the cautery to the grooves of the eye and destroy it. [translated by SummarizeBot]
E donc si al comensament del tieu cauteri perve entro al os, bo es; e sino, lahoras itera le cauteri una veguada o dos, si mestiers era; e layssa aquel ayssi per tres jorns, e aprop pausa sobre aquel coto am boder e enviro lu am enguent exsiccatiu entro que sia sanat.	And if at the beginning of your cauterization, you penetrate into the bone, then that is good; but if not, then repeat the cautery once or twice if necessary, and leave it in place for three days. Then place a clean cloth over it and apply drying ointment until it heals. [translated by SummarizeBot]
Mays si eran passatz xi dias e no es sanat, lahoras pausa sobre lu medicina aguda corrosiva entro que l’os sia descubert e sia ras segon que conveneys en le sieu capitol.	But if ten days have passed and it is not healed, then apply a sharp corrosive medicine to reveal the bone and scrape as necessary according to what is appropriate in its chapter. [translated by SummarizeBot]
E es autra manieyra de cauteri de fistula la qual alscus primiers diysero: enten al loc de la fistula e fen aquela e aprop pausa en aquela fissura camaen subtil del qual es la forma de lu: E fon en aquela la quantitat de i unc de plom fundut; e te la tua ma am camaem am bona retencio, e no sia maugut le malaute per so que le plom fundut no pervengua al huel de aquel; e cove que pausas sobre le huel del malaute coto enfus en album de huou o en aygua, quar plom adhureys le loc de la fistula e sana aquela per sanacio meravilhora.	Here is another method for cauterizing a fistula, which was mentioned earlier: understand the location of the fistula and open it up. Then place a fine probe into the opening, with a shape like this: The probe should be made of one ounce of molten lead. Hold the patient's eye gently but firmly with your hand, making sure not to harm them, so that the molten lead does not reach their eye. It is necessary to place a clean cloth soaked in egg white or water over the patient's eye, as molten lead adheres to the fistula and heals it miraculously. [translated by SummarizeBot]
E si la fistula es sanada am aquo que havem dit del cauteri e de la curacio, bo es; e sino, lahoras es necessari aministrar trauc del nas e reduzir la fistula al cors del nas segon que vindra en son loc propri.	If the fistula is healed by the cauterization and treatment described above, then that is good. But if not, then it is necessary to administer a probe through the nose and reduce the fistula into the nasal cavity as appropriate in its place.
Capitol .xviii.	Chapter 18.
De cauterizacio de la fendedura des potz.	On cauterization of a wound on the foot. [translated by SummarizeBot] [!translatorstop!] Chapter 18: Cauterization for Wounds on the Feet
Motas veguadas accideysso fissuras en las labias, e majorment en las labias dels enfantz.	Many small cracks often occur in the lips, especially in children's lips. [translated by SummarizeBot]
Donc cum tu curas aquelas fissuras am aquo que nos havem dit en las divisios e no aprofieyta la tua cura, lahoras igneys le cauteri petit cutellar segon aquesta forma que s’ensiec:	Therefore, if you treat these cracks with what we have mentioned in the divisions and your treatment is not effective, then heat up a small pen-shaped cautery with this shape as instructed:
